docs.lead_paragraph: A Utah woman who resisted her doctor's urging to have a Caesarean section and was charged with murder when one of her twins was stillborn received a sentence of 18 months probation after pleading guilty to two lesser charges of child endangerment. Judge Dennis M. Fuchs of Third District Court ordered that the woman, Melissa Ann Rowland, 28, receive mental health treatment. The conviction for child endangerment stems from the drugs that she admitted taking in her pregnancy and not her decision about the Caesarean. Kirk Johnson (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Probation In Caesarean Death

docs.abstract: Melissa Ann Rowland, who refused to have Caesarean section and was charged with murder when one twin was born stillborn, pleads guilty in Utah court to child endangerment for taking drugs during pregnancy; is given probation (S)
docs.snippet: A Utah woman who resisted her doctor's urging to have a Caesarean section and was charged with murder when one of her twins was stillborn received a sentence of 18 months probation after pleading guilty to two lesser charges of child endangerment....
